title: HBO Max Is Left Out of Amazon's, Roku's Platforms
summary: Parent WarnerMedia has yet to reach carriage deals with some distributors but landed one with Comcast on Wednesday. HBO Max was absent from the nation's two largest streaming players when it launched Wednesday, the result of increasingly frequent clashes between streaming services and distributors in an era where many actors are also direct competitors.

title: Twitter Plays Into Trump's Hands
summary: 'Fact-checking' tweets will encourage political regulation of speech.. Where would President Trump be if his critics didn't so often help him? The latest case is Twitter 's attempt Tuesday for the first time to fact-check Mr. Trump's tweet logorrhea. He wrote that mail-in voting this fall would be "substantially fraudulent," saying that California is sending ballots to anyone living in the state, "no matter who they are or how they got there."

title: Trump's Hong Kong Moment
summary: The President can send a message that targets Chinese officials.. China's National People's Congress will move this week to strip Hong Kong of the legal autonomy the territory was promised, and on Wednesday the U.S. made clear that will have consequences. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declined to certify that "Hong Kong maintains a high degree of autonomy from China," which under U.S. law can trigger sanctions and the withdrawal of trade and other benefits.

title: Europe Seeks Its 'Hamilton Moment'
summary: Too bad the EU skips over the part about democratic legitimacy.. Whatever else you might say about them, European Union mandarins aren't short of ambition. They have long wanted to knit the EU into a true federal union, and they're seizing the coronavirus as a €1.9 trillion opening.

title: Human Absurdity Stock: Not Depleted
summary: Did a Trump adviser use a 'dehumanizing' term with 'roots in slavery'?. Outrage politics rots the mind, and here's another tragic example: "White House adviser Kevin Hassett uses dehumanizing term for US workers," says a headline at Vox.com. AOC tweets: "Let's also not ignore the racial history of this terminology, which has roots in slavery."

title: Marathon Partners to Launch Proxy Fight With e.l.f. Beauty
summary: Director nominations by activists have been rare since the coronavirus emerged. Marathon Partners Equity Management LLC is planning to nominate three directors to e.l.f. Beauty Inc.'s board, a rare instance of an activist investor launching a proxy fight since the coronavirus shook American corporations.

title: U.S. Officially Declares That Hong Kong Is No Longer Autonomous
summary: 'It is now clear that China is modeling Hong Kong after itself,' said Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. WASHINGTON-The State Department determined that Hong Kong no longer has a high degree of autonomy from China, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said Wednesday in a statement likely to unsettle the global financial center and certain to aggravate Beijing.

title: AIDS Activist Larry Kramer Dies at 84
summary: Playwright and author helped found Gay Men's Health Crisis and ACT UP, two advocacy groups devoted to combating the epidemic. Larry Kramer, a playwright and author who fought for aggressive action to conquer the AIDS epidemic, died Wednesday in Manhattan at age 84.

title: U.S. to Stop Allowing Foreign Companies to Facilitate Iran's Civil Nuclear Program
summary: Tehran has 'continued its nuclear brinkmanship by expanding proliferation sensitive activities,' Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the U.S. would stop allowing foreign companies to facilitate Iran's civil nuclear activities, a core provision of the 2015 international nuclear agreement.

title: Buildings Beef Up Security in the Coronavirus Age
summary: You'll need to reveal more about your health than you used to if you want to get past the front desk.. The first time I received a vigorous pat-down at an airport it seemed outrageous. The first time my wife had a security officer poke through her purse, I remember thinking it was excessive. Now that stuff seems par for the course. Our desire to board a plane or enjoy a Broadway show remains undiminished. We all have the same experience, we all are put through it, because we accept that the balance of risk requires it.

title: Artificial Intelligence Can Serve Democracy
summary: The G-7 launches a new global partnership Thursday.. The U.S. is using every tool at its disposal to defeat the novel coronavirus, including artificial intelligence. American laboratories are harnessing AI to discover new therapeutics. The Food and Drug Administration approved an AI tool to help detect coronavirus in CT scans. And the White House led an initiative to create a database with more than 128,000 articles that scientists can analyze using AI to help understand the virus better and develop treatments.

title: Marxist Economic Policy-as in Groucho
summary: The unemployment bonus is straight out of 'Animal Crackers.'. We're all Marxists now. Not Karl, Groucho. There's a famous sketch in "Animal Crackers" (1930) in which Groucho (as Captain Spaulding) quizzes Chico (Signor Emanuel Ravelli) on how much money the band gets paid. "What do you fellas get an hour?" Groucho asks. "For playing we get $10 an hour," Chico replies.

title: What Is Joe Biden Talking About?
summary: 'You ain't black' got all the attention, but the interview showed his lack of coherence.. 'If you have a problem figuring out whether you're for me or Trump, then you ain't black," Joe Biden said Friday in an interview with Lenard Larry McKelvey, better known as "Charlamagne Tha God," a co-host of the popular "Breakfast Club" radio show. Then all hell broke loose.

title: New York State Lawmakers Pass Coronavirus Relief Bills
summary: One measure gives victims of childhood sexual abuse more time to sue responsible parties. ALBANY, N.Y.-Members of the state Assembly and Senate passed more than a dozen bills on Wednesday, including a measure giving victims of childhood sexual abuse more time to sue the responsible parties.

title: After the Covid Apocalypse
summary: Coronavirus lesson #1: The U.S. is willing to shut down for three months, but that's about it.. The threat in March of a Covid-19 apocalypse worked: From coast to coast, the $21 trillion U.S. economy essentially shut down. Today in all 50 states, the experience with coronavirus has peaked, plateaued or fallen, and the time has arrived to start identifying lessons learned.

title: 'Hollywood Park' Review: Turn the Broken Into Beauty
summary: Mikel Jollett, front man for The Airborne Toxic Event, has written a memoir that is dangerous, immediate and lyrical from the jump.. Choose your childhood: You get to be raised by an ex-heroin-addict, ex-prison-inmate father, or a mother whose narcissistic personality disorder is so profound that she will blame you for every one of her own selfish acts. Oh, and she also left you with a cult when you were 6 months old, to be raised as a child "of the universe."

title: Notable & Quotable: Human Capital
summary: 'A racially charged, dehumanizing turn of phrase that conjured up images of livestock.'. Aaron Ruparwriting for Vox.com, May 26, 2020:

title: Hertz Fleet Losing Value by the Day, Hindering Restructuring Efforts
summary: Creditors say vehicle fleet could rank among biggest value drops in U.S. bankruptcy history. The roughly 700,000 rental cars that are the lifeblood of Hertz Global Holdings Inc.'s business are losing value rapidly, posing a challenge to bondholders' repayment and to the bankrupt company's chances of weathering the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Trump Ramps Up Swing-State Travel
summary: President's trip to Florida is his fourth official visit to a campaign battleground in as many weeks. CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla-With swing-state locations, familiar rally playlists and political appeals from the candidate, President Trump's recent official White House outings have included many of the trappings of campaign stops.

title: GE Exits Lightbulb Business It Pioneered
summary: Company drops its last direct link to consumers in sale to Savant Systems. General Electric Co. is getting out of the business of making lightbulbs, selling a unit that defined the company for nearly a century and was its last direct link to consumers.

title: Does the Justice Department Need a Dedicated Compliance Expert?
summary: Overseeing the corporate compliance matters that arise in the course of investigating white-collar crime is a full-time job, says former prosecutor Andrew Weissmann. The Justice Department in recent years has issued a series of policies designed to incentivize companies to invest in programs that ensure employees don't violate the law.

title: Bad Weather Scrubs SpaceX Launch
summary: Wednesday's mission with NASA astronauts would have been the first from U.S. soil in nearly a decade; next chance is Saturday. SpaceX postponed the launch of two NASA astronauts into orbit Wednesday afternoon because of stormy weather, including a tornado warning, less than 20 minutes before the scheduled liftoff.

title: Macy's Prices $1.3 Billion in Bonds at 8.375%
summary: Retailer is said to have gotten $6 billion in orders. Macy's Inc. priced a total of $1.3 billion in five-year bonds Wednesday, pulling in buyers with a 8.375% interest rate.

title: The 1975's 'Notes on a Conditional Form' Review: Unconditionally Impressive
summary: The group's largest album yet is also their most ambitious-an 80-plus-minute journey through myriad genres..

title: Gov. Cuomo Has 'Good Conversation' With Trump Over Federal Aid
summary: Democratic governor blasts Republicans in U.S. Senate for withholding relief money. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo on Wednesday said he met with President Trump and urged him to help speed up major infrastructure projects in the state as it works to restart its economy amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: States Sue Trump Administration Over Easing of Auto Standards
summary: Lawsuit argues March action by administration violated law and was based on faulty analysis. A coalition of 23 states filed suit Wednesday against the Trump administration's March easing of tailpipe-emissions standards, arguing that it violated the law and was based on faulty analyses.

title: Stocks Climb as Optimism Builds
summary: Major indexes were again powered by economically sensitive shares in the financials and industrials sectors. U.S. stocks surged Wednesday, climbing to levels not seen since early March, on optimism that economic activity is gathering steam and authorities may offer more stimulus to bolster the recovery.

title: 'Jeffrey Epstein: Filthy Rich' Review: Another Kind of Contact Tracing
summary: A four-part exposé digs into Jeffrey Epstein's abuses and casts a shadow across his many high-profile friends and acquaintances..

title: Navigating Your Life During Coronavirus
summary: Most Popular News. As the coronavirus pandemic upends work, travel and home life, the rules are shifting for what people can and can't do in their daily lives. The WSJ is continuously updating advice and information on how to stay safe, healthy and connected, and how to help others. Here's our latest news, answering your questions:

title: The Stock Market and Consumer Sentiment Are Telling Different Stories
summary: Stocks have rebounded off March lows, while sentiment is near the lowest level in nearly a decade. Stocks have rebounded dramatically off their March lows, while consumer sentiment is hovering near the lowest level in nearly a decade. The divergence is one of many realities investors are struggling to reconcile.

title: Investors Buy Ralph Lauren's Timeless Pitch
summary: Focus on e-commerce and direct-to-consumer sales blunted coronavirus impacts in China, cushioning share prices as Ralph Lauren braces for a worse quarter. Ralph Lauren 's fashions may be timeless, but its business has kept up with the times.

title: Covid-19 Pandemic Hits Nursing-Home Finances
summary: Genesis Healthcare, others lean on federal support as costs rise, revenue falls. The biggest U.S. nursing-home company said its operations are being pressured by fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, pointing to a sharp drop in occupancy and rising expenses that are rippling through the entire elder-care sector.

title: 'Looney Tunes Cartoons' Review: Bugs Is Back
summary: HBO Max's reboot keeps intact much of what made the originals the acme of animated entertainment.. What's all the hubbub, bub? Well, the HBO Max streaming service makes its debut Wednesday, offering all the content of HBO's cable service plus new series, the Warner Bros. back catalog and children's programming-which includes, according to the corporate missives, a reboot of "Looney Tunes."

title: Canadian Judge Rules U.S. Met Legal Test to Seek Huawei Executive's Extradition
summary: Decision is first major court ruling in case of CFO Meng Wanzhou, who can appeal. A Canadian judge ruled that the U.S. met a key legal test to seek the extradition of a senior Huawei Technologies Co. executive who is at the center of a fight between Washington and Beijing over the giant telecom-equipment maker.

title: What to Watch: Hulu's 'Ramy' Grapples With God; Celebrities Read 'Harry Potter'
summary: Plus, two more comedies to add to your queue, from Apple TV+'s 'Central Park' to 'Schitt's Creek'. The big news in streaming this week is the arrival of HBO Max, a new service that brings together the prestige offerings of HBO with the broader catalog from WarnerMedia Entertainment. There are new series, like a crafting competition series for kids called "Craftopia," old reruns of "Friends," and hundreds of movies from the WarnerMedia vault, the Criterion Collection and the Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli. To read more about what to watch on HBO Max, see our companion piece here.

title: Travel and Hospitality Companies Want Customers to See Them Cleaning
summary: Before they can return to pre-pandemic profitability, travel-dependent businesses must win back customers' trust. Travel and leisure companies planning and hoping for the return of business are working to make sure customers feel safe.

title: U.S. Businesses See Few Signs of Recovery Through Mid-May
summary: Federal Reserve report on business conditions finds evidence of a continued labor-market slide, lower consumer spending. WASHINGTON-U.S. businesses saw limited evidence of a recovery in recent weeks, with economic activity continuing to decline amid the coronavirus pandemic, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday.

title: The Best James Bond Book for Summer-Especially This Summer
summary: 'From Russia, with Love,' Ian Fleming's magnum of espionage kitsch, is a guaranteed escape. For the highest-yield diversion, read the book first, then stream the movie.. SOMEWHERE, a thousand confinement novels are being written. But why wait when we already have "From Russia, With Love," starring James Bond and a stealth killer trapped inside a train compartment? For readers, escape is guaranteed: author Ian Fleming's 1957 page-turner veers from wondrous to ghastly in a sentence. In what's likely the novel's best-remembered scene, Bond watches a Bulgarian hit man exit his lair through the billboard-poster mouth of Marilyn Monroe (Anita Ekberg in the film). Second billing goes to the entrance of a lethally customized Swaine Adeney attaché case-after which spy tales would never be the same.

title: Investment in U.S. Shale Projects to Halve in 2020, IEA Says
summary: Energy sector's transition to renewables is also expected to slow, agency's director says.

title: U.S. Seizure of Chinese-Built Transformer Raises Specter of Closer Scrutiny
summary: Resume Subscription. A Chinese transformer weighing more than 500,000 pounds arrived by ship at the Port of Houston last summer, en route to an electrical substation in Colorado that funnels electricity to Denver.

title: The Fear vs. Hope Election
summary: Are November's results now out of the hands of the candidates?. Have Donald Trump and Joe Biden already made their most important campaign decisions? An influential political analyst argues that the results of the 2020 presidential election will now be determined by events largely outside of their control.

title: Push to Build Border Wall Gains Steam in Texas
summary: Laredo landowners begin defending themselves virtually as lockdown rules out live court hearings. LAREDO, Texas-Tony Medina sat at a desk in his home last week, surrounded by toolboxes and photos of his family. In front of him was a neatly printed four-page statement he had prepared for his virtual hearing to explain to a federal judge why he doesn't want the property he has owned for more than 40 years to be taken by the U.S. government for a border wall.

title: EU Plans $2 Trillion Coronavirus Response Effort
summary: If implemented, the plan would represent a historic step in knitting together member nations' finances. BRUSSELS-The European Union set out a $2 trillion coronavirus response plan, including a massive pooling of national financial resources that, if approved, would deepen the bloc's economic union in a way that even the eurozone debt crisis failed to achieve.

title: No Vacation? Why You Still Need a New Swimsuit
summary: The coronavirus has erased our summer plans, but a new bikini or one-piece can be an optimistic purchase, even just for socially distanced park hangs. SWIMSUIT SHOPPING is fraught, even in the best of times. Greeting my pale thighs and under-buttocks in a fitting-room mirror has never been my idea of fun, so my annual suit refresh is: Grab, go and hope for the best.

title: Fauci Warns About Hydroxychloroquine and In-Person Party Conventions
summary: Top administration expert airs differences with Trump on pandemic response. WASHINGTON-Anthony Fauci, the government's top infectious-disease expert, said hydroxychloroquine isn't an effective treatment for Covid-19 and urged caution as Republicans and Democrats plan their conventions for later this summer.

title: Investors Cheer Europe's Step Toward United Bond Market
summary: European Union proposes borrowing €750 billion from capital markets to aid recovery from coronavirus pandemic. Bond investors cautiously cheered a proposal by the European Union to issue centrally backed bonds for the first time, a move that attempts to address financial divisions that have long plagued the eurozone.

title: Disney World to Reopen Gradually Starting July 11
summary: Plans to protect against coronavirus include limited attendance, plexiglass barriers and a 'social-distancing squad'. Walt Disney Co. said it plans to begin reopening its Disney World theme park at reduced capacity in mid-July.

title: Larry Fink Should Focus on Clients' Interests
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink isn't being attacked because he is rich; it's because he has shown a willingness to adopt the left's agenda.. Regarding your editorial "Larry Fink's Political Purgatory" (May 23): I have a different take on BlackRock CEO Larry Fink's problems. He isn't being attacked because he is rich; it's because he has shown a willingness to adopt the left's agenda. As I see it, he made a very big mistake in pandering to the desires of the left, even a little. By buying into the climate argument and urging service to stakeholders instead of shareholders, he has become a wounded fish, now attracting predators. He showed the world of left-wing activists that he could be had. As they say, never show a weakness, because to do so will only cause your enemies to probe for more. They won't let up now that they've discerned his willingness to cooperate. For the good of BlackRock, he should leave and the board should disavow his positions and reaffirm its commitment to delivering strong returns to clients, regardless. Only then can the board expect relief from the left.

title: 'Backdoors' Invite Abuse of the Law Abiding
summary: Sooner or later the backdoors to encryption will be leaked, stolen or sold as well.. Regarding Thomas J. Baker's "Limit FISA Surveillance to Foreigners" (op-ed, May 19): Mr. Baker cites ample reasons why digital-device manufacturers should not bow to pressure from the Justice Department and FBI to provide them with backdoors to encryption, nor should Congress enact a law requiring "backdoors."

title: Open Skies Was a Very Marginal Agreement
summary: Its symbolic confidence-building value became moot as the Cold War ended and, evidently, adds little confidence today given Moscow's implementation obstruction.. Regarding your editorial "A Clear Decision on Open Skies" (May 22): Qualms about the demise of the Open Skies treaty are misplaced. As a State Department foreign affairs officer I was part of the team that negotiated the agreement. Seeking to hang its hat on a new arms-control initiative, the George H.W. Bush White House revived an idea that was appropriate for the Eisenhower era when aerial intelligence collection was limited to risky RB-47 and, later, U-2 flights over the Soviet Union. Attempting Open Skies made sense then because satellite intelligence had not gotten off the ground. In the Bush revival the interagency team worked diligently to fashion the best deal, but there was a clear consensus it was a waste of resources that would add little intelligence due to the dumbed-down sensor suite Washington preferred both sides to use to prevent Moscow from collecting sensitive information about the U.S.

title: We Americans Mostly Came Together in Wartime 1942
summary: The deep divisions that exist in our society today are unprecedented in my lifetime.. Regarding Paul Kennedy's review of Tracy Campbell's "The Year of Peril: America in 1942" (Books, May 23): I'm sure that Mr. Campbell has done an impressive amount of research and I know the reviewer to be an eminent historian, but my recollection is different than theirs. I was pretty young in 1942, but that period is indelibly impressed in my memory. To contend that Americans remained divided over many issues is a gross overstatement. Whatever divisions existed were swept away on Dec. 7, 1941. My father was a dedicated isolationist, but he was immediately converted by the attack on Pearl Harbor. I lived on the Pacific Coast where the seemingly unconstitutional act of placing Japanese Americans in camps won overwhelming approval. The rationing, blackouts and federal mandates were accepted as necessary by an overwhelming number of Americans.

title: Japan Bank's Foray Into Risky U.S. Debt Leaves $3.7 Billion Hole
summary: Norinchukin, which serves Japanese farmers and fishermen, was the biggest buyer of debt used to fund private-equity buyouts. The Japanese bank that was the biggest buyer of debt used to fund private-equity buyouts suffered a ¥400 billion ($3.7 billion) hit and said it would stop investing in that market.

title: Summer School Would Be Contractually Complicated
summary: These are huge financial barriers to a summer start.. Regarding Robert C. Hamilton's "Let Children Go to Summer School" (op-ed, May 19): As a teacher of computer-aided design, my New Jersey magnet-school classroom had 24 desktop computers, with students spaced less than 3 feet apart. The adjacent classrooms were for chemistry and biology, where frequent experiments were conducted with much less than the required 6 feet between learners. How will educational leaders safely accommodate social distancing in these settings, among sports and other competencies by summer? In addition, Mr. Hamilton doesn't address teacher contracts, which are typically for 10 months, along with other services, and reprogrammed curricula. These are huge financial barriers to a summer start. Finally, and notwithstanding Mr. Hamilton's "the child who tested positive . . . in the French Alps did not pass the virus on," how will schools deal with the multiple concerns (anxiety) of parents and grandparents? A more effective way to find solutions is to use systems thinking, and see you in September when the summer's through.

title: Tuesday Morning Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Discount-goods retailer expects to close a third of its stores over the summer. Discount home-goods retailer Tuesday Morning Corp. became the latest company to seek bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus pandemic continues to hamper retail even as government-mandated closures and social-distancing regulations are eased.

title: Why Does Zoom Exhaust You? Science Has an Answer
summary: On video calls, looming heads, staring eyes, a silent audience, and that millisecond delay disrupt normal human communication. Tammy Sun, the quintessential Silicon Valley tech entrepreneur, fired off an uncharacteristically low-tech Tweet recently. "Zoom fatigue has me wanting a landline and a rotary phone," wrote the founder and CEO of Carrot, a startup that provides fertility benefit plans for companies.

title: When Covid 'Science' Is a Smokescreen
summary: Like many politicians, Washington's Jay Inslee trusts the numbers only when they serve his purposes.. The word "science" has been hollowed out by politicians, who have stripped it of its substance and power and replaced them with emotional pabulum. These politicians discard the scientific method and deploy the term merely as a weapon against their opponents.

title: India Is a Natural U.S. Ally in the New Cold War
summary: America beat the Soviets by helping democracies get rich. In Asia, it's high time to revive that approach.. It's been an interesting week in India. A heat wave took temperatures up to 117 degrees in the sweltering north. An earthquake shook the northeastern state of Manipur as a massive cyclone slammed into coastal Odisha. Swarms of locusts have descended on cities and farms across the northwest. Record numbers of new cases were reported in India's rapidly escalating Covid-19 epidemic. Meanwhile, villagers in Kashmir spotted and captured a "spy pigeon" with a coded message attached to a ring on its leg. As the code has not yet been broken, the pigeon's mission remains unknown. Despite both a costly lockdown and a continuing surge in new Covid cases, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi continues to dominate the political scene, with approval ratings of 80% or more in recent polls.

title: New York Starts Mapping Out the Road Back From Coronavirus-and It's Long
summary: Resume Subscription. New York City's daily death toll from the coronavirus pandemic is receding. Its next chapter, staging an economic comeback, poses a whole new set of challenges.

title: Twitter Loves Your Rage Against Its Machine
summary: Social media seems to feed off the very contempt it breeds in its users. Social media companies are no strangers to controversy. That might be by design.

title: Women's Soccer League Announces June Return
summary: Questions remain about how many stars from the U.S. women's national team will play. While other American team sports leagues have pledged to return to the field soon from shutdowns or delays due to the coronavirus pandemic, the nation's top women's soccer league has named a date: June 27.

title: Le Pain Quotidien's U.S. Restaurants File for Bankruptcy
summary: Fast-casual dining chain hopes to sell itself to restaurant operator Aurify Brands for $3 million. The U.S. division of bakery chain Le Pain Quotidien filed for bankruptcy protection as pandemic restrictions continue to wreak havoc on fast-casual dining chains.

title: Online Auctions, Sidewalk Concerts and Virtual Tours
summary: Top specialists at Sotheby's, Christie's and elsewhere shift tactics to sell millions of dollars of art during lockdown.. Christie's Chairman Alex Rotter normally spends several days a week flying around the world persuading billionaires to let him see-and then sell-their art. This week, Mr. Rotter, working from his Bridgehampton, N.Y., home, connected online with a collector for a video tour instead. Lisa Dennison, Mr. Rotter's counterpart at rival Sotheby's, has her own working-from-home tactics for the coronavirus lockdown. She recently had a piece of art driven over to a prospective buyer's yard in upstate New York. "We held a front-lawn viewing," Ms. Dennison said, which ended in a sale.

title: Trump Offers to Mediate China-India Border Disputes
summary: Unsolicited effort follows rebuffed bid to mediate longstanding border disagreement between India and Pakistan. NEW DELHI-As border tensions have escalated between China and India in recent weeks, President Trump made an unsolicited offer early Wednesday to mediate the two countries' decades-old border disputes.

title: Republicans Open to More Election Funding, but Not on Democrats' Terms
summary: GOP lawmakers oppose requiring mail-in ballots nationwide, seek flexibility for state and local officials amid coronavirus pandemic. WASHINGTON-Republican leaders on Capitol Hill say they don't want the federal government telling states how to hold elections during the coronavirus pandemic. But they haven't closed the door on increased funding for local officials wrestling with how to keep voters safe this November.

title: For Hong Kong Dissidents, 'The Cost of Protest Is Exorbitantly High Now'
summary: Hundreds arrested as demonstrations against two controversial bills pop up across city. HONG KONG-Riot police faced off with protesters in several districts Wednesday, as thousands joined demonstrations across the city to oppose a bill that would criminalize disrespect of China's national anthem, as well as a national-security law that Beijing has vowed to impose on the city.

title: Fed's Williams: Economy May Be Bottoming As Fed Weighs Yield-Curve Control
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President sees space for a good rebound. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said on Bloomberg's television channel Wednesday the worst of the economy's decline from the coronavirus crisis may be over, even as he warned hard days still lie ahead in a climate of considerable uncertainty.

title: The Hamptons Summer House Share: Coronavirus Edition
summary: These New Yorkers reveal what it's like hunkering down long-term in vacation homes with a bunch of family, friends (and some people they hardly know). In the mass exodus of New Yorkers to the East End, most have isolated themselves with immediate family, emerging just to stroll on the beach or shop for food. A few big-hearted Hamptons homeowners have put aside personal fears and a desire for privacy, opening their homes to guests and inviting them to trade the current dangers of elevators and Ubers for the lure of lawns, fresh air and lots of space. And these invitations weren't for a weekend or even a week-the urban refugees have no exit strategy in sight.

title: Rental-Car Company Advantage Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Private equity-owned Advantage follows rival Hertz in chapter 11. The parent company of Advantage Rent a Car filed for bankruptcy protection, the second big car-rental company to seek protection from creditors in less than a week as travel restrictions from the coronavirus pandemic continue to ripple through the economy.

title: Hunkering Down, Hamptons Style
summary: These homeowners on the East End are using their vacation properties like never before.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Virus Attacks Philanthropy
summary: The pandemic is exposing the ailments of philanthropic enterprises, and revealing creative cures to organizational woes.. The coronavirus pandemic has dealt a severe blow to nonprofit organizations, the roughly two million groups that form the backbone of American community life. Some, such as hospitals and food banks, have had unprecedented demands for their services. Others, including schools and museums, have stopped operating, lost large amounts of revenue, laid off skilled staff, and in some cases face the possibility of closing altogether. As the economy contracts, individual donations are expected to fall, as they did during the financial crisis a decade ago.

title: New York City Teachers Worry About 'Covid Slide'
summary: After 10 weeks of remote learning, students who are struggling will likely need more than remedial summer school. When Kirk Schneider started teaching his high-school geometry classes remotely in late March because of the coronavirus pandemic, he expected that many of the 300,000 New York City students who didn't have computer access might initially fall behind.

title: HBO Max Is Here: What You Need to Know
summary: There's no 'Friends' reunion, but with new releases like 'Craftopia' and classics like 'The Wizard of Oz,' the new platform has a broad mix of offerings. The latest mega streamer is now open for business, with a sales pitch that the name HBO Max translates to quality and quantity.

title: Biden Weighs New Climate Proposals to Woo Sanders Supporters
summary: Republicans portray presumptive Democratic nominee as a threat to the oil and gas industry. Joe Biden says he will add details to his climate plan and is likely to propose new investments, an olive branch to Bernie Sanders and his liberal allies. But in battleground states such as Pennsylvania, Republicans are already portraying Mr. Biden as a threat to the oil-and-gas industry.

title: Recyclers Stuck With Millions of Uncashed Empties in Lockdown
summary: Resume Subscription. Michiganders are sitting on $60 million worth of empty bottles and cans, a lot of them rattling around in the back of Thad Zajac's Ford Escape.

title: Unemployed? Try Reselling Clothes on eBay or Poshmark
summary: Internet marketplaces have reported an uptick in people flipping clothes as a way to generate extra income and fill the idle hours at home. AT THE END OF MARCH, Diana Karen Mireles was furloughed from her job as a marketing coordinator at a Los Angeles shoe store, yet still managed to pay off a longstanding car loan within weeks. How did she pull off this budgetary wizardry? By raking in over $3,000 selling her old clothes on Poshmark, an online resale marketplace. "Most of it is things that I just haven't worn and that have been taking up space in my closet," said Ms Mireles, of the more than 200 pairs of shoes, sweats and other clothing items she unloaded.

title: Holed-Up New Yorkers Down Drinks Outside
summary: Bars and restaurants serve takeout drinks-and patrons linger to the consternation of authorities. Drinking from an open container in public is against the law in New York.

title: Researchers Outside Medicine Have a New Focus: Covid-19
summary: Engineers, physicists, volcanologists and others who never dreamed they would work on a deadly pandemic are now part of the global effort to understand and contain the coronavirus. Rajat Mittal spent a decade exploring how our larynxes generate sound and the physics behind blood flow. Now the fluid dynamics expert is wholly absorbed in a new scientific quest: to understand how droplets of moisture spread the new coronavirus from person to person.

title: Just North of Chicago, a Small Room With Big Views
summary: This 210-square-foot sitting room is framed by floor-to-ceiling windows that look out onto Lake Michigan. "We wanted to keep the outside the star," said Ben Stringfellow of the 210-square-foot living area he designed for a young family whose modern home is perched on a hill in the northern Chicago suburbs, overlooking Lake Michigan. While it seamlessly blends with the rest of the Wheeler Kearns Architects-designed home, it wasn't in the original plans. "As the home was being built, we realized there was no warm, cozy living space," said Mr. Stringfellow. "My idea was to create a separate space, a couple steps down from the main dining and living areas."

title: As Lockdown Rules Ease, Some Want to Keep Working From Home
summary: Employers make plans to allow many of their staffers to continue working remotely when the crisis ends. As states begin to lift the stay-at-home restrictions put in place to combat the coronavirus pandemic, some workers now say they are just fine working from home and would like to do so permanently.

title: The New Way to Wear Pearls
summary: Diamonds reimagined and fresh, unconventional new takes on pearl jewelry that would impress even Vermeer. Cultured pearls and diamonds cascade in a graceful bib-style necklace with a jeweled clasp and ornate elements. Chanel Fine Jewelry necklace, price upon request, Chanel Fine Jewelry boutiques

title: André Leon Talley on the Time He Scandalized Paris Society
summary: In a borrowed look from Karl Lagerfeld, no less. The fashion veteran and 'Chiffon Trenches' memoirist reflects on the meaning of "duty" with five other luminaries.. "It's a moral duty to dress well. Well means appropriate for your circumstance, environment or position. When I lived in Paris in the '70s, I had to go to a black-tie party at Maxim's. Karl Lagerfeld suggested I wear something from his wardrobe: a beautiful black chevron cashmere dressing gown. When I walked into Maxim's-it was a very Oscar Wilde look-tongues wagged. Parisian society was scandalized. But scandalized in an innocent way. What they really saw was a person who had achieved a certain moment in his career where he could afford to do that. It represented a kind of individuality and freedom, the way Charles Baudelaire might have done in the 19th century. There's not necessarily a certain way one must dress. One must dress well according to how you see yourself in society."

It represented a kind of individuality and freedom, the way Charles Baudelaire might have done in the 19th century. There's not necessarily a certain way one must dress. One must dress well according to how you see yourself in society."

title: Nissan, Renault to Divide Up World Markets in Cost-Cutting Push
summary: New strategy aims to reassure employees and shareholders that the 20-year-old partnership has a future. The Renault-Nissan alliance said Wednesday they would divide up their global car business, aiming to cut duplicate spending to save billions of dollars a year.

title: The Doctor and the 'Badasses' Keeping NFL Players Safe From the Coronavirus
summary: Dr. Thom Mayer dealt with the Sept. 11 attacks at the Pentagon and anthrax bioterrorism. Now he's the chief doctor guiding NFL players through the pandemic.. There was a red phone in the communications center at Inova Fairfax Hospital in Virginia, just outside of Washington. It rang only when the hospital needed to prepare for an imminent crisis. Nobody ever wanted that red phone to ring.

title: CEOs Call in the Coaches as Covid-19 Tests Their Companies
summary: Business leaders with long-term leadership coaches say tough feedback has prepared them for the challenges of the pandemic. Executives are turning to their longtime coaches to help them navigate the uncertainty-and unprecedented leadership challenges-presented by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Millions of Indians Are Fleeing Cities, Raising Fears of a Coronavirus 'Land Mine' in Villages
summary: A historic reverse-migration to rural regions is under way: 'The situation in our area is like a hidden land mine waiting to explode'. NEW DELHI-More than 10 million of India's suddenly jobless migrant workers are moving from cities back to their home villages, a historic reverse-migration that brings with it concerns about a new wave of coronavirus cases and social unrest in some of the poorest, least prepared places.

title: Weddings Are Off, but Marriage Is On
summary: Jewelers report gains in sales of engagement rings, as coronavirus lockdowns spark surge in proposals. When the coronavirus pandemic forced Timothy Flynn to shelter at home in Chesapeake, Va., he was unable to see his girlfriend, who lives three hours away.

title: Italy Reopens but Milan's Chinese Follow a Cautious Path
summary: Country's large Chinese community began locking down before the official quarantine began, and it is slower to exit, too. MILAN-While Italy has been opening in stages after one of the longest and strictest lockdowns among Western countries, its sizable Chinese community is moving more cautiously, concerned the pandemic isn't yet under control.

title: Sanofi to Sell Regeneron Shares Worth $11.1 Billion to Fund Overhaul
summary: Health-care giant is expected to spend proceeds on deals. Sanofi SA plans to offload most of its long-held stake in Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc., giving the company an $11.1 billion war chest to help reshape its drug pipeline as it doubles down on rare-disease and cancer medicines.

title: 'Vaccine Nationalism': New Dynamic in the Race to Quash Coronavirus
summary: International pursuit for a shot is shifting into a contest of which world power can immunize its population first. Pharmaceutical companies are bracing for export bans on future coronavirus vaccines and spreading production across different continents, on early signs of a high-stakes geopolitical scramble to secure supplies for a scientific breakthrough that could confer enormous economic and political power.

title: This Isn't Your Father's Corporate-Bond Market
summary: Central banks and tracker funds have upended the way prices are set in the credit market, but the new system could be better for businesses. Corporate bonds have never been so popular. Are they a safer investment than they used to be in a downturn, or just riding a wave of central-bank and index-fund money? Both could be true.

title: Average Tenure of CMOs Falls Again
summary: But ranks of top marketers became more diverse in 2019, Spencer Stuart study finds. Marketing leaders' average time in their posts slipped again in 2019.

title: Companies Lean on Freight Technology to Untangle Scrambled Supply Chains
summary: High demand driven by the coronavirus pandemic has distributors seeking rapid adjustments, real-time 'visibility' to keep goods moving. Technology designed to streamline supply chains in a prepandemic world is helping businesses cope with coronavirus-driven upheaval, from providing help adjusting to volatile swings in demand to tracking delivery of critical supplies.

title: Fannie and Freddie's Capital Dilemma
summary: A new proposal would give the mortgage firms a sizable capital cushion to protect taxpayers but could complicate their potential public offerings. It seems that there is never a simple answer when it comes to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac .

title: Miss Your Office? Some Companies Are Building Virtual Replicas
summary: Demand for simulated office space may grow as more employers embrace remote work. Stay-home orders and the shuttering of workplaces have given corporate employees some respite from getting dragged into time-wasting water-cooler conversations.

title: Borrower, Beware: Credit-Card Fraud Attempts Rise During the Coronavirus Crisis
summary: Emboldened fraudsters are mounting phishing attacks and attempting purchases with card numbers stolen in old hacks. Fraudsters are increasingly using pilfered credit-card numbers and phishing attacks to prey on overwhelmed consumers and banks during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: How to Protect Yourself From Card Fraud
summary: Around 11 million Americans fall victim to credit- and debit-card fraudsters each year. Phoebe Flanigan received a text message in April from Wells Fargo & Co. that warned of suspicious purchases on her debit card. When the New York City resident logged into her account, she saw that dozens of purchases had been made in Brazil.

title: Tech Workers Fear Their Jobs Will Be Automated in Wake of Coronavirus
summary: Concern about automation among tech workers exceeds that in other industries, KPMG says. Technology-sector employees are particularly worried about being replaced by automation, including tools used by employers to cope with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, according to KPMG LLP.

title: Sick of Cleaning? Turn It Into Meditation
summary: Household chores that require gentle concentration can steer the mind from future or past worries and provide a sense of control. Feel the warmth of the water as you wash plates. Note the weight of an iron as you extend your arm back and forth. Observe how you hold your body as you vacuum. Cleaning a window? Take pleasure in each movement of the cloth against the glass.

title: Japan Offers an Investment Haven Whichever Way the Pandemic Goes
summary: Internationally exposed Japanese stocks will benefit if the global recovery is faster than expected, but also have the mountainous cash holdings to outperform if things go wrong. With the world's eyes on the gravity-defying performance of the S&P 500, Japan's listed companies have quietly done what they've spent most of the last decade doing: matter-of-factly outperforming.

title: Stocks Finish Higher on Optimism Over Reopening
summary: The New York Stock Exchange's famed trading floor reopens, with new social-distancing rules in place. Stocks surged Tuesday on optimism about economies reopening and the potential development of a coronavirus vaccine, extending a rally that has pushed major U.S. indexes up more than 30% since late March.

title: Minneapolis Police Clash With Protesters Angered by George Floyd's Death
summary: Four officers are fired after video showed black man in custody saying he couldn't breathe while neck was pinned to ground for around five minutes. Minneapolis police clashed with protesters Tuesday angry over the death of a black man in police custody, hours after four officers involved in the incident had been fired.

title: Plumber's Safety Protocols Are Now Standard Procedure
summary: Bryan Hammons's business took slight productivity, profit hits from new precautions but plans to stick with them; 'Stuff still has to get done'. Bryan Hammons faced a difficult choice over whether to keep his St. Petersburg, Fla., plumbing business open during the pandemic. His seven employees counted on a paycheck, but his immunocompromised 4-year-old son could be exposed to Covid-19 if Mr. Hammons worked in homes or businesses of potentially infected people.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Twitter Adds Fact-Check Notices to Trump Tweets on Mail-In Ballots
summary: Move follows earlier appeal by widower that president's false tweets about death of his wife be pulled down. WASHINGTON-Twitter Inc. on Tuesday for the first time applied a fact-checking notice to a tweet from President Trump, hours after the social-media company denied a widower's request to delete the president's posts circulating conspiracy theories about his wife's death.

title: Trump Urges Republicans to Vote Against Renewing a Set of Surveillance Powers
summary: House is expected to vote this week on legislation concerning aspects of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. WASHINGTON-President Trump called on House Republicans to reject pending legislation that would renew a set of domestic surveillance powers that lapsed two months ago, a move that could doom the bill less than 24 hours before lawmakers were set to begin consideration of it.

title: Amazon in Advanced Talks to Buy Self-Driving-Car Tech Company Zoox
summary: Deal expected to value Zoox at less than its last private valuation. Amazon . com Inc. is in advanced talks to buy Zoox Inc. in a move that would expand the e-commerce giant's reach in autonomous-vehicle technology.

title: House Republicans Move to Block Proxy Voting
summary: Lawmakers were set to begin new method starting Wednesday; GOP to sue in federal court. WASHINGTON-Far-flung Democratic lawmakers locked down partners Tuesday ahead of the first proxy votes in congressional history, while Republicans went to court to try to stop the change.

title: Pandemic Lockdowns Loosen as U.S. Deaths Near 100,000
summary: Crowds hit beaches in Florida, Italy; protections on foreclosures and evictions lifted. Reopenings accelerated in the U.S. and across the world as falling numbers of coronavirus cases and slowing death rates in some regions fueled hopes that the worst of the pandemic was over.

title: Justice Department Closes Insider-Trading Probes Into Three Senators
summary: Probe continues into stock trades that GOP Sen. Richard Burr of North Carolina made earlier this year. The Justice Department is closing investigations into three U.S. senators for stocks trades made shortly before the coronavirus market turmoil, but is continuing a related investigation into GOP Sen. Richard Burr, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Game Plan: Their Income Took a Coronavirus Hit. Here's Some Advice.
summary: A Philadelphia couple has lost a lot of their income. A financial adviser offers suggestions on how to deal with it.. Daniel and Laurel Eng lost a chunk of their income at the onset of the coronavirus pandemic and have suspended all of their debt payments.

title: Boeing, Airbus Study Coronavirus on Flights
summary: Industry is working to curb pandemic risks that have brought air traffic to a near standstill. Boeing Co. and Airbus SE are researching the new coronavirus's behavior inside jetliners, part of an industry push to curb risks that have brought air traffic to a near standstill.

title: I Survived Covid-19. So Many Other Black Americans Haven't.
summary: The guilt I've felt over my modest financial stability has taught me a lot about privilege and community.. I was sitting at the kitchen table in my lower Harlem apartment when I heard what sounded like luggage being yanked from my roommate's closet. It was mid-March, exactly one day before Gov. Andrew Cuomo would sign the "New York state on PAUSE" executive order that would bring Manhattan and its boroughs to a crawl.

title: In Valuing Colleges, Tops in Prestige Doesn't Always Mean Tops in Starting Salaries
summary: New research suggests that choosing the right program can matter more than the reputation of the school.. The value of a college degree has traditionally been pegged to the prestige of the college itself. But new research suggests that choosing the right program of study can matter more than a prestigious diploma when it comes to good starting salaries.

title: What Late Tax Filers Need to Know
summary: Tips and tax-law twists to keep in mind as the July 15 deadline approaches. Thanks to the pandemic, millions of us have even more time than usual to procrastinate on our 2019 tax returns.
